previous_statement: ORBIT BLOCKS: The r blocks in the ⟨σ⟩-orbit of B are exactly the blocks intersecting supp(σ). These are B, σ(B), σ²(B), ..., σ^{r-1}(B).
new_statement: ORBIT BLOCKS: The r blocks in the ⟨σ⟩-orbit of B are exactly the blocks intersecting supp(σ). Forward: B ∩ supp(σ) ≠ ∅ and σ permutes supp(σ), so σⁱ(B) ∩ supp(σ) ≠ ∅ for all i. Converse: If B' ∩ supp(σ) ≠ ∅, pick x ∈ B' ∩ supp(σ) and y ∈ B ∩ supp(σ). Since σ acts transitively on supp(σ), σⁱ(y) = x for some i. Then x ∈ σⁱ(B) ∩ B', so B' = σⁱ(B) (blocks are disjoint or equal). Thus B' is in the orbit of B.
